segment.source: Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) brings the power of Microsoft Windows together with breadth of the Internet of Things.
segment.target: Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) brings the power of Microsoft Windows together with breadth of the Internet of Things.

segment.source: Developers can now build and provision their own custom Windows 10 images for the IoT Core devices in their ecosystem.
segment.target: Developers can now build and provision their own custom Windows 10 images for the IoT Core devices in their ecosystem.

segment.source: IoT Core deployment and imaging
segment.target: IoT Core deployment and imaging

segment.source: IoT Core deployment and imaging
segment.target: IoT Core deployment and imaging

segment.source: Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) brings the power of Microsoft Windows together with breadth of the Internet of Things.
segment.target: Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) brings the power of Microsoft Windows together with breadth of the Internet of Things.

segment.source: Developers can now build and provision their own custom Windows 10 images for the IoT Core devices in their ecosystem.
segment.target: Developers can now build and provision their own custom Windows 10 images for the IoT Core devices in their ecosystem.

segment.source: Intended audience
segment.target: Intended audience

segment.source: OEMs and ODMs customizing and deploying images for IoT devices.
segment.target: OEMs and ODMs customizing and deploying images for IoT devices.

segment.source: Download and install the kits and packages
segment.target: Download and install the kits and packages

segment.source: Before you can create an IoT Core image, you must first install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) as well as the IoT Core Core OS Packages.
segment.target: Before you can create an IoT Core image, you must first install the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK) as well as the IoT Core Core OS Packages.

segment.source: Download the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK)
segment.target: Download the Windows Assessment and Deployment Kit (ADK)

segment.source: Download the IoT Core OS Packages.
segment.target: Download the IoT Core OS Packages.

segment.source: When these installations are complete, verify that you have directories called FMFiles, MSPackages, and OEMInputSamples in your computer’s C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10 directory.
segment.target: When these installations are complete, verify that you have directories called FMFiles, MSPackages, and OEMInputSamples in your computer’s C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10 directory.

segment.source: Create an image
segment.target: Create an image

segment.source: You have two options for tools to use to create an image for IoT Core.
segment.target: You have two options for tools to use to create an image for IoT Core.

segment.source: Create an image with IMGGEN
segment.target: Create an image with IMGGEN

segment.source: Create an image with Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).
segment.target: Create an image with Windows Imaging and Configuration Designer (ICD).

segment.source: Later in this topic, you will also learn how to customize packages, which will require that you create an image using one of these tools.
segment.target: Later in this topic, you will also learn how to customize packages, which will require that you create an image using one of these tools.

segment.source: Which tool you use is up to you.
segment.target: Which tool you use is up to you.

segment.source: Option One: Create an image with IMGGEN
segment.target: Option One: Create an image with IMGGEN

segment.source: The Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, or IMGGEN, is a command-line alternative to the Image Configuration Designer.
segment.target: The Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment, or IMGGEN, is a command-line alternative to the Image Configuration Designer.

segment.source: Image creation can be automated or completed through scripting using IMGGEN.
segment.target: Image creation can be automated or completed through scripting using IMGGEN.

segment.source: Open Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment application by typing Deployment and Imaging Tools Environmentin the Search bar.
segment.target: Open Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment application by typing Deployment and Imaging Tools Environmentin the Search bar.

segment.source: Set the following environment variables, in the following order:
segment.target: Set the following environment variables, in the following order:

segment.source: Execute the following commands based on your device environment:
segment.target: Execute the following commands based on your device environment:

segment.source: Intel Minnowboard Max:
segment.target: Intel Minnowboard Max:

segment.source: Raspberry Pi 2 or Qualcomm Dragonboard:
segment.target: Raspberry Pi 2 or Qualcomm Dragonboard:

segment.source: Option Two: Create an image with Windows ICD
segment.target: Option Two: Create an image with Windows ICD

segment.source: To create an IoT Core image with Windows ICD, see Build and deploy a Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) image.
segment.target: To create an IoT Core image with Windows ICD, see Build and deploy a Windows 10 IoT Core (IoT Core) image.

segment.source: The following sections describe how to customize the image.
segment.target: The following sections describe how to customize the image.

segment.source: Create customized OEM configuration packages
segment.target: Create customized OEM configuration packages

segment.source: Regardless of the tool you use to create your image, be it IMGGEN or Windows ICD, you may need to customize packages for the devices you deploy for branding or to enable unique scenarios.
segment.target: Regardless of the tool you use to create your image, be it IMGGEN or Windows ICD, you may need to customize packages for the devices you deploy for branding or to enable unique scenarios.

segment.source: The applications, certificates, and settings on a device may need to be configured to match your specifications.
segment.target: The applications, certificates, and settings on a device may need to be configured to match your specifications.

segment.source: This requires custom packages.
segment.target: This requires custom packages.

segment.source: Create the packages
segment.target: Create the packages

segment.source: The process for creating a package is the same for IoT Core as it is for Windows 10 Mobile.
segment.target: The process for creating a package is the same for IoT Core as it is for Windows 10 Mobile.

segment.source: Refer to Creating mobile packages for instructions to create your package.
segment.target: Refer to Creating mobile packages for instructions to create your package.

segment.source: Installing test certificates
segment.target: Installing test certificates

segment.source: OEM test certificates provide a trust relationship to package signatures.
segment.target: OEM test certificates provide a trust relationship to package signatures.

segment.source: They need only be installed once.
segment.target: They need only be installed once.

segment.source: In order to install the test certificates,
segment.target: In order to install the test certificates,

segment.source: Open the deployment and imaging tools environment (IMGGEN) with administrator privileges.
segment.target: Open the deployment and imaging tools environment (IMGGEN) with administrator privileges.

segment.source: Set environment variables with the following commands:
segment.target: Set environment variables with the following commands:

segment.source: Install OEM certificates with the following utility command:
segment.target: Install OEM certificates with the following utility command:

segment.source: Verify that W10KITROOT is set to %ProgramFiles%Windows Kits10.
segment.target: Verify that W10KITROOT is set to %ProgramFiles%Windows Kits10.

segment.source: Author the feature manifest xml
segment.target: Author the feature manifest xml

segment.source: XML files define the content of each step of the package creation and deployment process.
segment.target: XML files define the content of each step of the package creation and deployment process.

segment.source: Windows ICD and IMGGEN depend on an OEM Input file, located in the %KITSROOT%OEMInputSamplesdevice directory (for instance C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10OEMInputSamplesMBM ).
segment.target: Windows ICD and IMGGEN depend on an OEM Input file, located in the %KITSROOT%OEMInputSamplesdevice directory (for instance C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10OEMInputSamplesMBM ).

segment.source: This OEM Input file refers to a platform feature manifest file.
segment.target: This OEM Input file refers to a platform feature manifest file.

segment.source: This file contains a list of packages to be included in the created image, and references to additional required or optional OEM feature manifest files.
segment.target: This file contains a list of packages to be included in the created image, and references to additional required or optional OEM feature manifest files.

segment.source: For more information, see OEMInput file contents.
segment.target: For more information, see OEMInput file contents.

segment.source: The feature manifest file references the packages and cabinet files (CAB) to be included in the image.
segment.target: The feature manifest file references the packages and cabinet files (CAB) to be included in the image.

segment.source: For more information, see Feature manifest file contents.
segment.target: For more information, see Feature manifest file contents.

segment.source: For more information about how packages are used in building images, see Provisioning packages.
segment.target: For more information about how packages are used in building images, see Provisioning packages.

segment.source: Three OEM feature manifest files for IoT Core are provided as samples in the directories below.
segment.target: Three OEM feature manifest files for IoT Core are provided as samples in the directories below.

segment.source: Intel Minnowboard Max C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesx86MBMFM.xml
segment.target: Intel Minnowboard Max C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesx86MBMFM.xml

segment.source: Raspberry Pi 2 C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmRPi2FM.xml
segment.target: Raspberry Pi 2 C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmRPi2FM.xml

segment.source: Qualcomm Dragonboard 410c C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmQCDB410CFM.xml
segment.target: Qualcomm Dragonboard 410c C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmQCDB410CFM.xml

segment.source: These manifests contain the following sections:
segment.target: These manifests contain the following sections:

segment.source: Base package
segment.target: Base package

segment.source: System information package
segment.target: System information package

segment.source: Device information package
segment.target: Device information package

segment.source: Device platform package
segment.target: Device platform package

segment.source: Feature based package
segment.target: Feature based package

segment.source: You can add base packages and features packages, which go into the base package and feature based package sections, respectively.
segment.target: You can add base packages and features packages, which go into the base package and feature based package sections, respectively.

segment.source: Here is an example OEM feature manifest file.
segment.target: Here is an example OEM feature manifest file.

segment.source: Here are examples of packages that you can include in your IoT Core feature manifest file.
segment.target: Here are examples of packages that you can include in your IoT Core feature manifest file.

segment.source: In each case, the package must be part of an OEMFM.xml file.
segment.target: In each case, the package must be part of an OEMFM.xml file.

segment.source: Adding a file to an image.
segment.target: Adding a file to an image.

segment.source: Adding a registry setting to an image.
segment.target: Adding a registry setting to an image.

segment.source: Adding a driver to an image.
segment.target: Adding a driver to an image.

segment.source: Generate the packages
segment.target: Generate the packages

segment.source: Add a reference to the OEMFM.xml file in the OEM Input XML file named RetailOEMInput.xml for retail devices, or ProductionOEMInput.xml for production devices.
segment.target: Add a reference to the OEMFM.xml file in the OEM Input XML file named RetailOEMInput.xml for retail devices, or ProductionOEMInput.xml for production devices.

segment.source: The package generator tool (pkggen.exe) generates packages and cabinet files (.CAB) for inclusion in the IoT Core image.
segment.target: The package generator tool (pkggen.exe) generates packages and cabinet files (.CAB) for inclusion in the IoT Core image.

segment.source: This tool is installed by default in %WPDKCONTENTROOT%Toolsbin.
segment.target: This tool is installed by default in %WPDKCONTENTROOT%Toolsbin.

segment.source: Open the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment command prompt with administrator privileges.
segment.target: Open the Deployment and Imaging Tools Environment command prompt with administrator privileges.

segment.source: Issue the appropriate PKGGEN command for each of the packages to be added to the image.
segment.target: Issue the appropriate PKGGEN command for each of the packages to be added to the image.

segment.source: PKGGEN for a driver:
segment.target: PKGGEN for a driver:

segment.source: PKGGEN for file or registry entry:
segment.target: PKGGEN for file or registry entry:

segment.source: Note The /version field of a modified package should always be incremented when running package generator
segment.target: Note The /version field of a modified package should always be incremented when running package generator

segment.source: Copy all OEM packages to the directory that maps to your device’s architecture.
segment.target: Copy all OEM packages to the directory that maps to your device’s architecture.

segment.source: For example: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailx86fre
segment.target: For example: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailx86fre

segment.source: Adding an OEM package during image creation
segment.target: Adding an OEM package during image creation

segment.source: To add an OEM package to an IoT Core image as part of the image creation process, complete the following steps:
segment.target: To add an OEM package to an IoT Core image as part of the image creation process, complete the following steps:

segment.source: Author the package as described above and add it to the OEM packages directory for the device's architecture (for instance C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailx86fre.
segment.target: Author the package as described above and add it to the OEM packages directory for the device's architecture (for instance C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailx86fre.

segment.source: Add a feature manifest file (OEMFM.xml) and copy it to the feature manifest file directory (for instance C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesx86)
segment.target: Add a feature manifest file (OEMFM.xml) and copy it to the feature manifest file directory (for instance C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesx86)

segment.source: Add references to the OEM feature manifest file and Feature ID in OEMInputFML.xml under both the Production and Retail folders.
segment.target: Add references to the OEM feature manifest file and Feature ID in OEMInputFML.xml under both the Production and Retail folders.

segment.source: Create a new image as described above using either Windows ICD or IMGGEN.
segment.target: Create a new image as described above using either Windows ICD or IMGGEN.

segment.source: Adding OEM Packages to a deployed image at runtime
segment.target: Adding OEM Packages to a deployed image at runtime

segment.source: To add an OEM package to an IoT Core image as part of the image creation process, complete the following steps:
segment.target: To add an OEM package to an IoT Core image as part of the image creation process, complete the following steps:

segment.source: Copy the package to the device
segment.target: Copy the package to the device

segment.source: Connect to the device via SSH or Powershell
segment.target: Connect to the device via SSH or Powershell

segment.source: Run these commands
segment.target: Run these commands

segment.source: The device will reboot into the Update OS, complete the installation, and then reboot back to the main OS.
segment.target: The device will reboot into the Update OS, complete the installation, and then reboot back to the main OS.

segment.source: Depending on the package size, this step can take up to 10 minutes.
segment.target: Depending on the package size, this step can take up to 10 minutes.

segment.source: Adding OEM FM file and optional features to the OEM Input XML
segment.target: Adding OEM FM file and optional features to the OEM Input XML

segment.source: There are two sample features manifest files installed as part of IoT Core Kits.
segment.target: There are two sample features manifest files installed as part of IoT Core Kits.

segment.source: You can find them here.
segment.target: You can find them here.

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10OEMInputSamplesMBMProductionOEMInput.xml
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10OEMInputSamplesMBMProductionOEMInput.xml

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10OEMInputSamplesMBMRetailOEMInput.xml
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10OEMInputSamplesMBMRetailOEMInput.xml

segment.source: Authoring OEM Customization Packages
segment.target: Authoring OEM Customization Packages

segment.source: The OEMCustomization.cmd utility allows customization at device boot time.
segment.target: The OEMCustomization.cmd utility allows customization at device boot time.

segment.source: During each boot sequence, this script file is invoked as a result of a scheduled task.
segment.target: During each boot sequence, this script file is invoked as a result of a scheduled task.

segment.source: The OEMCustomization.cmd script file is not present in the image by default, and needs to be authored by the OEM.
segment.target: The OEMCustomization.cmd script file is not present in the image by default, and needs to be authored by the OEM.

segment.source: The customizations below are allowed and suggested:
segment.target: The customizations below are allowed and suggested:

segment.source: Activate a user with Administrator-level privileges on the device Net user Administrator "insert desired Administrator password" /active:yes by authoring OEMCustomization.cmd.
segment.target: Activate a user with Administrator-level privileges on the device Net user Administrator "insert desired Administrator password" /active:yes by authoring OEMCustomization.cmd.

segment.source: You'll have to create a password to replace "insert desired Administrator password" in the code example below.
segment.target: You'll have to create a password to replace "insert desired Administrator password" in the code example below.

segment.source: Enable OEM application installation.
segment.target: Enable OEM application installation.

segment.source: Author the OEMCustomization.pkg.xml to point to the OEMCustomization.cmd script.
segment.target: Author the OEMCustomization.pkg.xml to point to the OEMCustomization.cmd script.

segment.source: Create the CAB File for the package using pkggen.exe.
segment.target: Create the CAB File for the package using pkggen.exe.

segment.source: Enable Bitlocker.
segment.target: Enable Bitlocker.

segment.source: OEM apps
segment.target: OEM apps

segment.source: To help get you started writing apps for IoT Core, we've uploaded some batch files to GitHub.
segment.target: To help get you started writing apps for IoT Core, we've uploaded some batch files to GitHub.

segment.source: You'll need to download those files from https://github.com/ms-iot/samples/tree/develop/AppInstall
segment.target: You'll need to download those files from https://github.com/ms-iot/samples/tree/develop/AppInstall

segment.source: Copy these files to the C:OEM directory on your development compute.
segment.target: Copy these files to the C:OEM directory on your development compute.

segment.source: Note Files from GitHub may not display in a friendly format for notepad and may need to be opened in a development environment like Visual Studio.
segment.target: Note Files from GitHub may not display in a friendly format for notepad and may need to be opened in a development environment like Visual Studio.

segment.source: Copy the APPX and CET files to C:OEM.
segment.target: Copy the APPX and CET files to C:OEM.

segment.source: Edit the AppInstall.bat script file
segment.target: Edit the AppInstall.bat script file

segment.source: Set defaultappx = your appx’s file name
segment.target: Set defaultappx = your appx’s file name

segment.source: Set certslist = your appx’s certificates’ names (multiple certificates may be added, separated by a space)
segment.target: Set certslist = your appx’s certificates’ names (multiple certificates may be added, separated by a space)

segment.source: Edit the DeployApp.bat file
segment.target: Edit the DeployApp.bat file

segment.source: Set defaultappx = your appx’s file name
segment.target: Set defaultappx = your appx’s file name

segment.source: Set defaultappid = your appx’s ID
segment.target: Set defaultappid = your appx’s ID

segment.source: Set depenencylist = include this if your appxes have dependencies that are required to be installed prior to your appx.
segment.target: Set depenencylist = include this if your appxes have dependencies that are required to be installed prior to your appx.

segment.source: Multiple dependency names are allowed, separated by space.
segment.target: Multiple dependency names are allowed, separated by space.

segment.source: Note Note: OEMs must choose an application that runs on the device "out-of-the-box", by default.
segment.target: Note Note: OEMs must choose an application that runs on the device "out-of-the-box", by default.

segment.source: This application will never be updated.
segment.target: This application will never be updated.

segment.source: The operating system needs to switch back to the OOBE for this installation to ensure there is no resource conflict during the application’s installation or update
segment.target: The operating system needs to switch back to the OOBE for this installation to ensure there is no resource conflict during the application’s installation or update

segment.source: Author the application package, called OEMApp.pkg.xml, as in the following example.
segment.target: Author the application package, called OEMApp.pkg.xml, as in the following example.

segment.source: Place the created files and related resources in directories of the development device as follows:
segment.target: Place the created files and related resources in directories of the development device as follows:

segment.source: C:Windowsappinstall:
segment.target: C:Windowsappinstall:

segment.source: appx
segment.target: appx

segment.source: dependency appx(s)
segment.target: dependency appx(s)

segment.source: temp appx (optional)
segment.target: temp appx (optional)

segment.source: certificate(s)
segment.target: certificate(s)

segment.source: AppInstall.bat
segment.target: AppInstall.bat

segment.source: DeployApp.bat
segment.target: DeployApp.bat

segment.source: C:Winodwssystem32:
segment.target: C:Winodwssystem32:

segment.source: Oemcustomization.cmd
segment.target: Oemcustomization.cmd

segment.source: Restart the device.
segment.target: Restart the device.

segment.source: The specified appx will be installed automatically when the device restarts.
segment.target: The specified appx will be installed automatically when the device restarts.

segment.source: Image-time configurations
segment.target: Image-time configurations

segment.source: The following are examples of configuration settings you may want to include in your OEMImageCustomization.cmd.
segment.target: The following are examples of configuration settings you may want to include in your OEMImageCustomization.cmd.

segment.source: Headless configuration
segment.target: Headless configuration

segment.source: Crash dump configuration
segment.target: Crash dump configuration

segment.source: Run-time configurations
segment.target: Run-time configurations

segment.source: The allowed runtime settings listed below should be included in a provisioning package generated with Windows ICD.
segment.target: The allowed runtime settings listed below should be included in a provisioning package generated with Windows ICD.

segment.source: These settings must be included in a single provisioning package and the provisioning package should be wrapped into a single OEM package.
segment.target: These settings must be included in a single provisioning package and the provisioning package should be wrapped into a single OEM package.

segment.source: Certificates
segment.target: Certificates

segment.source: Firewall configuration
segment.target: Firewall configuration

segment.source: Startup app
segment.target: Startup app

segment.source: Edition upgrade
segment.target: Edition upgrade

segment.source: Policies update
segment.target: Policies update

segment.source: Configuring IoT Core update settings
segment.target: Configuring IoT Core update settings

segment.source: To configure an image to receive only OS updates, you must configure generic POP packages.
segment.target: To configure an image to receive only OS updates, you must configure generic POP packages.

segment.source: Generic POP packages exist in the following locations; replace them with the examples from the list below.
segment.target: Generic POP packages exist in the following locations; replace them with the examples from the list below.

segment.source: Intel Minnowboard Max
segment.target: Intel Minnowboard Max

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailX86freIntel.Generic.DeviceInfo.cab
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailX86freIntel.Generic.DeviceInfo.cab

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailX86freIntel.Generic.DeviceTargetingInfo.cab
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailX86freIntel.Generic.DeviceTargetingInfo.cab

segment.source: Replace with: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesx86MBMFM.xml
segment.target: Replace with: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesx86MBMFM.xml

segment.source: Raspberry Pi 2
segment.target: Raspberry Pi 2

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre RASPBERRYPI.Generic.DeviceInfo.cab
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre RASPBERRYPI.Generic.DeviceInfo.cab

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre RASPBERRYPI.Generic.DeviceTargetingInfo.cab
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre RASPBERRYPI.Generic.DeviceTargetingInfo.cab

segment.source: Replace with: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmRPi2FM.xml
segment.target: Replace with: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmRPi2FM.xml

segment.source: Qualcomm Dragonboard 410c
segment.target: Qualcomm Dragonboard 410c

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre Qualcomm.Generic.DeviceInfo.cab
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre Qualcomm.Generic.DeviceInfo.cab

segment.source: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre Qualcomm.Generic.DeviceTargetingInfo.cab
segment.target: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10MSPackagesRetailARMfre Qualcomm.Generic.DeviceTargetingInfo.cab

segment.source: Replace with: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmQCDB410CFM.xml
segment.target: Replace with: C:Program Files (x86)Windows Kits10FMFilesarmQCDB410CFM.xml

segment.source: Creating an enterprise IoT Core UAP provisioning package
segment.target: Creating an enterprise IoT Core UAP provisioning package

segment.source: To create an enterprise provisioning package that you can deploy to a IoT Core device, follow these steps.
segment.target: To create an enterprise provisioning package that you can deploy to a IoT Core device, follow these steps.

segment.source: Download the IoT Core license file to the development device.
segment.target: Download the IoT Core license file to the development device.

segment.source: More information about this step can be found at IoT Core Commercialization.
segment.target: More information about this step can be found at IoT Core Commercialization.

segment.source: Create a new provisioning package containing a license file by selecting "New provisioning package" in Windows ICD, as in the following image, and then click Next.
segment.target: Create a new provisioning package containing a license file by selecting "New provisioning package" in Windows ICD, as in the following image, and then click Next.

segment.source: In the Enter Project Details window, enter a Name, Project folder, and optionally a Description of the provisioning package, then click Next.
segment.target: In the Enter Project Details window, enter a Name, Project folder, and optionally a Description of the provisioning package, then click Next.

segment.source: In the Select Windows Edition window, select IoT Core, then click Next.
segment.target: In the Select Windows Edition window, select IoT Core, then click Next.

segment.source: In the optional Import a provisioning package window, click Finish.
segment.target: In the optional Import a provisioning package window, click Finish.

segment.source: In the Customizations page, add the upgradeeditionwithlicense customization.
segment.target: In the Customizations page, add the upgradeeditionwithlicense customization.

segment.source: this customization provides a license for an edition upgrade of iot core devices.
segment.target: this customization provides a license for an edition upgrade of iot core devices.

segment.source: Export the provisioning package by clicking the Export dropdown in the main menu, then selecting Provisioning Package, adding the required package information and specify options for the package.
segment.target: Export the provisioning package by clicking the Export dropdown in the main menu, then selecting Provisioning Package, adding the required package information and specify options for the package.

segment.source: Click Next and then specify where the package will be saved.
segment.target: Click Next and then specify where the package will be saved.

segment.source: Click Build to start building the image.
segment.target: Click Build to start building the image.

segment.source: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.
segment.target: The project information is displayed in the build page and the progress bar indicates the build status.

segment.source: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.
segment.target: If you need to cancel the build, click Cancel.

segment.source: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.
segment.target: This cancels the current build process, closes the wizard, and takes you back to the Customizations Page.

segment.source: During the image build process, a lot of what's happening during the build process is shown in the build output window.
segment.target: During the image build process, a lot of what's happening during the build process is shown in the build output window.

segment.source: This window shows:
segment.target: This window shows:

segment.source: Warnings that might appear while the image is building.
segment.target: Warnings that might appear while the image is building.

segment.source: Verbose build messages to indicate the phases within the image build process.
segment.target: Verbose build messages to indicate the phases within the image build process.

segment.source: Error messages such as when the input files have schema errors or when the image fails to build.
segment.target: Error messages such as when the input files have schema errors or when the image fails to build.

segment.source: If your build fails, an error message will be displayed.
segment.target: If your build fails, an error message will be displayed.

segment.source: You can review the build log to identify the issue by clicking View in Notepad.
segment.target: You can review the build log to identify the issue by clicking View in Notepad.

segment.source: If your build is successful, the name of the image and its location will be displayed.
segment.target: If your build is successful, the name of the image and its location will be displayed.
